questions.text: A female patient presented with complaint of hairloss since 4 months. She gives history of covid 8 months back, What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Telogen effluvium is a form of nonscarring alopecia characterized by diffuse, often acute hair shedding.
  • Normally, 85% of a healthy person's hair is in the anagen (growth) phase, and 15% is in the telogen (resting) phase. Telogen effluvium occurs when a significant stressor triggers a large number of anagen hairs to abruptly shift to the telogen phase, causing increased shedding.
  • Common triggers include acute febrile illnesses, severe infections, major surgery, severe trauma, and hormonal changes such as those postpartum.
  • In this case, the patient's history of COVID-19, an illness that can serve as a significant stressor, is a likely cause. The shedding typically starts 3-4 months after the trigger and may last less than six months.
  • Telogen effluvium is a self-limited condition, meaning it often resolves on its own without the need for specific treatment.

Incorrect Answers:

  • Anagen effluvium: This type of hair loss is characterized by a rapid shedding of hair from the anagen phase, often due to chemotherapy or other forms of significant damage to the hair follicle. It doesn't typically follow the course seen with telogen effluvium.
  • Androgenetic alopecia: This is a genetic condition causing gradual, patterned hair thinning, often seen in both men and women. It is not typically linked to a specific event like COVID-19.
  • Trichotillomania: This is a psychological disorder where an individual pulls out their own hair. It does not result from physiological stressors like COVID-19 and has distinct behavioral characteristics.

Key Takeaway:

  • Telogen effluvium is commonly triggered by physiological stress such as severe illness (like COVID-19) and leads to diffuse hair shedding 3-4 months after the event. It is usually self-limiting and resolves within six months.

questions.text: A patient presents with nail lesions. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Nail psoriasis can present with a variety of changes depending on the part of the nail unit affected. Common features of nail psoriasis include:
    • Nail pitting: Coarse, irregular pits in the nail surface.
    • Salmon patch: A reddish-brown discoloration on the nail plate.
    • Onycholysis: Separation of the nail from the nail bed.
    • Red spots in the lunula, leukonychia (white spots), and crumbling of the complete nail plate are indicative of matrix involvement.
    • Oil drop discoloration, subungual hyperkeratosis, and splinter hemorrhages suggest nail bed involvement.
  • These features collectively point towards the diagnosis of nail psoriasis.

Incorrect Answers:

  • Lichen planus: Lichen planus can cause nail changes, but its clinical features are distinct, often including longitudinal ridging, thinning, and a characteristic "tree bark" appearance of the nail plate.
  • Alopecia areata: Alopecia areata typically causes patchy hair loss and does not commonly affect the nails in the way psoriasis does.
  • Onychomycosis: Fungal nail infections cause thickening, discoloration, and brittleness of the nails, but do not present with the specific features seen in psoriasis, such as pitting and oil drop discoloration.

Key Takeaway:

  • Nail psoriasis is characterized by distinct features such as pitting, onycholysis, and oil drop discoloration. It can affect both the nail matrix and nail bed, resulting in various nail abnormalities.

questions.text: A female patient with BMI 30 presented with the following neck lesion. Which of the following is associated with this?
questions.solution:
• The neck lesion described in the image is acanthosis nigricans, which is characterized by velvety hyperpigmentation of the skin, commonly found in the neck area.
  • Acanthosis nigricans is associated with various conditions, particularly metabolic syndrome, which includes:
    • Obesity
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Insulin resistance
  • It can also be linked to:
    • Hyperandrogenism
    • Cushing syndrome
    • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
    • HAIR-AN syndrome: A rare subphenotype of PCOS, which combines hyperandrogenism, insulin resistance, and acanthosis nigricans.
  • Certain medications like nicotinic acid, corticosteroids, and oral contraceptives can also lead to acanthosis nigricans.
  • In rare cases, it is associated with gastric adenocarcinoma.

Incorrect Answers:

  • Addison's disease: Addison's disease is not typically associated with acanthosis nigricans, but with symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, and hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas, not the neck.
  • Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism can cause various skin changes like dry skin and hair thinning but is not linked to acanthosis nigricans.
  • Parathyroid disorder: Parathyroid disorders (e.g., hyperparathyroidism) do not typically present with acanthosis nigricans. They are more associated with changes in calcium metabolism and bone health.

Key Takeaway:

  • Acanthosis nigricans is most commonly associated with metabolic syndrome, which includes obesity, diabetes mellitus, and insulin resistance. It can also occur in conditions such as PCOS, hyperandrogenism, and Cushing syndrome.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing treatment for borderline tuberculoid leprosy presents with a lesion involving the forehead, nose and bilateral cheeks. What is the nerve involvement here?
questions.solution:
• Cranial nerve involvement is a recognized complication of leprosy, occurring in 10-17% of patients. The facial and trigeminal nerves are the most commonly affected.
  • The trigeminal nerve is the best answer in this case because the patient has a lesion involving the forehead, nose, and bilateral cheeks-areas that are innervated by the trigeminal nerve.
  • The trigeminal nerve has three branches:
    • Ophthalmic (V1)
    • Maxillary (V2)
    • Mandibular (V3)
  • Leprosy can cause sensory loss in these areas and might present with anesthesia or hypoesthesia along the affected dermatome.

Incorrect Answers:

  • Abducens nerve: This nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for eye abduction. It is not typically involved in leprosy, especially with lesions on the face.
  • Trochlear nerve: The trochlear nerve controls the superior oblique muscle of the eye and does not relate to facial skin lesions seen in leprosy.
  • Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve is responsible for sensation in the medial aspect of the hand and motor function of some hand muscles. It is not involved in facial lesions.

Key Takeaway:

  • Trigeminal nerve involvement is common in leprosy, especially in lesions affecting the face, such as the forehead, nose, and bilateral cheeks. It can lead to sensory deficits in the regions innervated by the nerve.

questions.text: A farmer having trauma on lower limb following which a cauliflower like growth develops. Biopsy shows copper penny bodies. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Chromoblastomycosis, also known as Verrucous dermatitis, is a chronic fungal infection caused by dematiaceous fungi, which are pigmented molds.
  • Causative agents include Fonsecaea pedrosoi and Phialophora verrucosa.
  • The disease typically presents as rough, warty, cauliflower-like lesions on trauma-prone areas of the body, most commonly on the foot.
  • The hallmark feature on histopathology is the presence of medlar bodies or copper penny bodies, which are sclerotic bodies found in tissue samples.

Incorrect Answers:

  • Sporotrichosis: This fungal infection, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, typically presents with nodules along the lymphatic drainage following trauma, but it does not show copper penny bodies on biopsy.
  • Phaeohyphomycosis: This is caused by a different group of fungi and typically presents with a more variable clinical appearance, often involving brain and skin, and does not characteristically show copper penny bodies.
  • Mycetoma: Mycetoma is a chronic infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually caused by bacteria or fungi, and presents with nodules, sinus tracts, and pus discharge, but it does not show copper penny bodies.

Key Takeaway:

  • Chromoblastomycosis presents with cauliflower-like lesions and is diagnosed by the presence of copper penny bodies (medlar bodies) on biopsy, typically seen in trauma-prone areas like the feet.

questions.text: What is the causative agent of anogenital wart?
questions.solution:
• Anogenital warts, also known as condyloma acuminatum, are primarily caused by the Human Papillomavirus (HPV).
  • Around 75% of cases are caused by HPV-6, and the remainder are typically caused by HPV-11.
  • These warts are typically soft, pink, elongated, and sometimes filiform or pedunculated in appearance. They can occur asymptomatically but may cause discomfort, discharge, or bleeding.
  • The most common sites of occurrence are areas of coital friction, such as the frenulum, corona, and glans in men, and the posterior fourchette in women.
  • The growth of these warts may be enhanced during pregnancy due to hormonal changes.

Incorrect Answers:

  • HPV 2: HPV-2 is typically associated with cutaneous warts, not anogenital warts.
  • HPV 5: HPV-5 is associated with epidermodysplasia verruciformis, a rare condition, but not anogenital warts.
  • HPV 8: HPV-8 is associated with Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus and is not related to anogenital warts.

Key Takeaway:

  • The main causative agents of anogenital warts are HPV-6 and HPV-11, with HPV-11 being a common cause. These warts typically appear in areas of coital friction and may become more pronounced during pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient presents with 0.3 cm nodule on the medial canthus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin malignancy, often occurring in sun-exposed areas.
  • Clinical appearance: BCC typically presents as a pearly white, dome-shaped papule with prominent telangiectatic surface vessels. It may also appear as a shiny, well-defined plaque with rolled-up borders and a central erosion, which can bleed upon touch or scratching.
  • BCC is generally painless and can appear as a small nodule or growth, often on the medial canthus (inner corner of the eye).
  • Pigmented BCC can sometimes appear darker due to the presence of melanin.
  • It does not have a premalignant lesion and is directly related to sun exposure.

Incorrect Answers:

  • Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC): SCC typically appears as a firm, smooth, or hyperkeratotic papule or plaque, often with central ulceration. It is not usually associated with the pearly appearance of BCC.
  • Melanoma: Melanoma generally appears as an irregularly shaped, multicolored lesion, and is associated with rapid growth, bleeding, or ulceration, but does not match the typical characteristics of BCC.
  • Mycosis fungoides: Mycosis fungoides is a form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma and presents as erythematous, scaly patches, not a small nodule like BCC.

Key Takeaway:

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common skin cancer and often presents as a pearly, dome-shaped nodule with rolled borders and a central erosion. It is primarily associated with sun exposure and does not have a premalignant lesion.
